title_sort: william e. vandemark to walt whitman, 2 november 1863
title: William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 2 November 1863
text: Dear FatherI now take the plesure[pleasure] of fulfilling my promace[promise] a writing to you hoping those few lines will find you well 1 am getting better fasti[I] am at home now i[I] got home after noon my famly[family] is well i[I] left washington[Washington] wensday[Wednesday] we got to Jursey[Jersey] city thursday[Thursday] twelve oclock then we was taken to davids[David's] islind[Island] and then friday[Friday] they gave us passes for 8 days i[I] will come to brooklin[Brooklyn] sunday[Sunday] morning i[I] wish that yo[you] would meet me at fulten[Fulten] street fery[ferry] i[I] long to see yo[you] and have a long talk with yoIt rains here this morning and to day is lection[election] one of my neighbor men runs for member of assembly he is a good union man and i[I] hope that he will get elected for he is a good union man—i[I] am in the hospittle[hospital] on davids[David's] island up the east river the hospittle[hospital] is very large and nice place we have nice breazes[breezes] of wind all the wile[while] i[I] suppose that there will hef[have] to be some heavy fiting[fighting] soon agen[again] the rain :has made very hiwater[high water] herei[I] am soon going to lection[election] to go the union ticket hope the state will go union all throughthe poor for us their prayers will send for blessing rich and endless and was not Jesus poor a friend to us—else poor and friendly that through his poverty and pain we might the bliss of angels gain a christian help the needywell father i[I] will close now with giveing yo[you] the addresswrite soon for i[I] long to heer[hear] from yo[you] from William E Vandemark to his father good by William E. Vandemark to Walt Whitman, 2 November 1863
